user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FDGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_FDGetInfo(osal_id_t filedes, OS_file_prop_t *fd_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    OS_object_token_t   token;
    int32               return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(fd_prop);

    memset(fd_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_file_prop_t));

    /* Check Parameters */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, filedes, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_stream_table, token);

        if (record->name_entry != NULL)
        {
            strncpy(fd_prop->Path, record->name_entry, sizeof(fd_prop->Path) - 1);
        }
        fd_prop->User    = record->creator;
        fd_prop->IsValid = true;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_FDGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      Path[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    osal_id_t User;
    uint8     IsValid; /* For backward compatibility -- always true if OS_FDGetInfo returned true */
} OS_file_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_stream_table
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memset(fd_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_file_prop_t));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. fd_prop is declared as OS_file_prop_t * in the function signature and is checked for NULL via OS_CHECK_POINTER; the memset size is sizeof(OS_file_prop_t), which matches the pointed-to type. Therefore the memset does not inherently access beyond the bounds of the referenced object. (Only if a caller incorrectly passes a pointer to a smaller object or an incorrectly cast pointer could an out‑of‑bounds access occur, but that is a caller misuse, not a violation in this function.)
